ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is mostly a reading/writing course but you also watch movies. Class is mostly a discussion and you learn about current issues in France such as the topic of national identity, the environment, education, etc.

This class is a lot of work. Four to five hours of homework in preparation for each of three weekly classes. I took it to brush up on my high school French before taking French literature classes. My section was small so we had a lot of opportunity to speak, which was nice. The reading material is quite boring â kind of a general overview of current issues in France, such as immigration and the environment, as well as a bunch of fairly useless information about the French schooling system and employment rules. My writing and vocabulary definitely improved, but I think a literature or history class would have been a much more interesting base for a conversation class.

Lots of work. An interesting class, but a tough one, and probably not the right one if you still need to fine-tune grammar or other linguistic aspects of French rather than simply focusing on culture.
I would recommend it only if you don't mind working hard and taking a class with a lot of technical terms. You will be much better versed in current topics.
